newsitem.title: UK: UK rail consortium sets first stand-alone PFI bond.
newsitem.headline: UK rail consortium sets first stand-alone PFI bond.

text.p: A bond launched on Friday to finance a cross-Thames railway link was the first under the British government's so-called private finance initiative (PFI) not to carry a third party guarantee.
"This is the first unenhanced PFI bond, whose structure is strong enough for the bond to stand on its own merits," said an official at BZW, lead manager of the 165 million stg issue.
Under PFI, the government aims to shift the capital cost and risk of major new public investments into public hands and then buy back use of the services on a lease-type basis.
City Greenwich Lewisham Rail Link Plc (CGLR), which issued the bond, was today awarded the contract to build an extension to the Docklands Light Railway into south-eastern London.
CGLR will receive payment from Docklands Light Railway for designing, building and maintaining the line for 25 years.
The deal is only the second capital market transaction under PFI. Road Management Consolidated (RMC) set the first in March -- a 165 million stg 25-year bond at 80 basis points over gilts.
RMC paid U.S. insurer AMBAC to unconditionally guarantee principal and coupon payments. The paper was rated triple-A by Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
The CGLR deal matures in 2020 but the paper has an average life of 16.2 years. Launched at a 130 b.p. spread over the 2017 gilt, the issue was trading at 125 b.p. over.
The bonds have preliminary single-A rating from Duff and Phelps.
The buyers were mainly British institutions, BZW said.
The funds will go towards the 200 million stg project. A government spokeswoman said 200 million stg was the final price and could not altered if costs over-ran.
CGLR's main contractors are Mitsui UK and John Mowlem, with backing also provided by London Electricity and Hyder, the Welsh water and electricity utility, BZW said.
